I hold a lot of nostalgia for the old PopCap games. I have tons of fond memories from when I was small—playing a bunch of them with my mother on our old family computer. A game I remember watching her play a fair few times was Insaniquarium. It was always a demo version hosted on various websites, as at the time she didn't want to spend money on a full version of the game. I bought the game back on Christmas of last year as a part of a bundle deal that included Insaniquarium as well as a bunch of other early PopCap games. I had never gotten to experience the entirety of what Insaniquarium had to offer. So I decided I was going to do my younger self a massive favour and finally beat the game. 

Even after these (to date) 22 years have passed it's still such a classic! The game may have originally came out in 2001, but it still holds up to this day. The game never gets old. I'm happy my curiosity had gotten the better of me that day in late December upon remembering the game's existence. Insaniquarium will always have a special place in my heart with its colourful and iconic roster of characters and magnificent soundtrack!

Insaniquarium, released in 2001, is undoubtedly one of the best games ever created. This classic game combines addictive gameplay, unique mechanics, and a delightful visual experience that captivates players even after two decades.



One of the key reasons why Insaniquarium stands out is its addictive gameplay. The objective of the game is to manage an aquarium filled with various fish species while protecting them from aliens. The challenge lies in feeding and nurturing the fish while defending them from extraterrestrial threats. This combination of strategy and action keeps players engaged for hours on end.



Moreover, Insaniquarium's mechanics are truly innovative. Players can collect coins dropped by their fish to purchase upgrades or new species, enhancing their aquarium's functionality and aesthetics. This progression system adds depth to the gameplay and motivates players to keep advancing.



Additionally, Insaniquarium's vibrant visuals contribute to its timeless appeal. The colorful graphics and charming character designs create a visually pleasing experience that appeals to gamers of all ages. The lively animations bring the aquatic world to life, making it an immersive journey for players.



In conclusion, Insaniquarium has rightfully earned its title as one of the best games ever made due to its addictive gameplay, innovative mechanics, and captivating visuals. Even after two decades since its release in 2001, this classic game continues to capture the hearts of gamers worldwide with its enduring charm and entertainment value.

Insaniquarium Deluxe is a colorful and addictive virtual aquarium game that offers a unique blend of strategy, simulation, and casual gameplay. Originally released in 2004 by PopCap Games, it has gained a loyal following and remains a popular choice for players seeking a light-hearted and entertaining experience.

The game revolves around managing an aquarium filled with various aquatic creatures. Your primary objective is to feed and care for the fish, ensuring they grow and multiply while fending off alien invaders. As you progress, you can purchase additional fish species, upgrade your tank, and unlock new items to enhance the gameplay.

One of the standout features of Insaniquarium Deluxe is its charming and vibrant graphics. The visuals are simple but lively, with colorful fish and quirky animations that bring the aquarium to life. The soundtrack and sound effects complement the gameplay perfectly, adding a delightful layer of immersion to the experience.

Gameplay in Insaniquarium Deluxe is accessible and easy to grasp, making it suitable for players of all ages and skill levels. The core mechanics involve feeding your fish by dropping pellets into the tank, collecting coins they produce, and using those coins to buy more fish and power-ups. As you progress, you'll face increasingly challenging levels and encounter various obstacles, such as alien attacks and hungry predators, which add an element of excitement and strategy to the game.

Insaniquarium Deluxe offers multiple game modes, including a story mode with different levels to complete and a virtual tank mode where you can customize your aquarium to your heart's content. Additionally, there's a time trial mode that tests your efficiency in managing the tank within a limited time frame.

While Insaniquarium Deluxe provides hours of enjoyable gameplay, some players may find it repetitive over extended periods. The core mechanics remain largely the same throughout the game, and once you've mastered the strategies, the challenge may diminish. However, the game's replayability is enhanced by the sheer variety of fish species to collect and the customization options available in the virtual tank mode.

In conclusion, Insaniquarium Deluxe is a delightful and engaging game that offers a perfect balance between casual fun and strategic thinking. With its charming visuals, catchy soundtrack, and addictive gameplay, it's easy to get hooked on the world of Insaniquarium. Whether you're a fan of virtual pets or simply looking for an entertaining and relaxing gaming experience, this game is definitely worth checking out.

139969052.review:
This game is a relic of a bygone era, when resource-gathering clicker games weren't shoving ads and microtransactions in your face every 2 seconds. It's just one level after another where you feed your fish and protect them from alien attacks. No artificial wait times, no BS. The basic campaign can be cleared in one sitting, but there are unlockables and some challenging extra modes afterward. The music is great and the helper pets let you customize your play style. I loved Insaniquarium when it first released and I'm having a great time replaying it now. Highly recommended if you want a casual game to breeze through. 

The downside is that this game is controlled with the mouse only, and there are no keybinding options. If you have any carpal-tunnel-type wrist problems, the amount and intensity of clicking will probably cause you some pain, although certain helper pets can alleviate the burden somewhat. Also, the resolution settings are very limited because HD monitors didn't exist at the time of release. If you're a stickler for crisp, high-fidelity graphics, you're going to hate looking at this game in full-screen mode.

[h1]Dive into the Hilarious Chaos of Insaniquarium! Deluxe[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Get ready for a wild and wacky underwater adventure with Insaniquarium! Deluxe. This quirky and humorous game, developed by Flying Bear Entertainment, will have you laughing and tapping your fins in sheer delight. With its addictive gameplay, colorful characters, and absurd antics, Insaniquarium! Deluxe is a delightful aquatic escapade like no other.

[h1]Fishy Fun and Financial Frenzy[/h1]
In Insaniquarium! Deluxe, you become the proud owner of a fish tank filled with a wide array of finned friends. Your goal? Keep them fed, happy, and protected from an array of eccentric enemies. As you feed your fish, they grow and produce valuable coins that can be used to buy upgrades and unlock even more outrageous fish. But watch out for those pesky aliens who are always ready to stir up trouble and snatch your precious swimmers!

[h1]Quirky Characters and Crazy Contraptions[/h1]
The cast of characters in Insaniquarium! Deluxe is nothing short of hilarious. From the ravenous guppies to the feisty swordfish and the unpredictable aliens, each fish has its own unique personality that will keep you entertained and on your toes. As you progress, you'll unlock crazy contraptions like laser guns and egg-firing machines to help defend your aquatic companions. Who knew fishkeeping could be this uproarious?

[h1]Absurd Antics and Fishy Frenzy[/h1]
Insaniquarium! Deluxe takes the term "fish tank" to a whole new level. The chaos that ensues in your little underwater paradise is simply absurd and guaranteed to have you in stitches. You'll witness fish doing flips, aliens causing mayhem, and explosive feeding frenzies that will leave you gasping for air (figuratively, of course). It's a lighthearted and zany experience that never fails to bring a smile to your face.

[h1]Endless Entertainment and Silly Surprises[/h1]
With its multiple game modes, unlockable content, and unpredictable events, Insaniquarium! Deluxe offers endless hours of laughter and entertainment. Whether you're aiming for high scores in Time Trial mode or just enjoying the unpredictable antics in Virtual Tank mode, there's always something new and silly waiting for you. You never know what surprises are lurking in your tank!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Insaniquarium! Deluxe is a hilarious and addictive underwater extravaganza that will keep you hooked with its goofy charm and outrageous gameplay. Dive into this aquatic world filled with eccentric fish, mischievous aliens, and fishy fun. It's a lighthearted and entertaining experience that will leave you grinning like a Cheshire cat. So get ready to dive in, have a splash, and let the insanity begin in Insaniquarium! Deluxe!

139214282.review:
I have a small memory of playing this game a long time ago, on a flash game site. I recently found out about it again from a youtube channel, and so I got it on steam to try it out once more. 

Back then, I didn’t fully grasp how the game worked and I found it to be too hard so I stopped playing it. But now, that I’m much older, I expected to beat it but I didn’t. 

The game really punishes the player in a lot of ways, and levels close to the end after around 4-4 started to take upwards of 16-24 minutes to beat. I didn’t want to put myself through much more torture so I stopped playing. I won’t be playing this game ever again.


The Good
The artstyle is very good. It’s unique and cartoony.
The music is alright.
The unique characters that you unlock were cool and weird in some cases. I liked that.

There’s some kind of pet simulator mode where you can take care of fishes. You can buy special fish that may appear each day? You can also use it as a screensaver, I think.


The Bad
The gameplay is good but you had to click so much. My right hand started to hurt from all the clicking, and I had to take a small break. I truly feel that no one should be playing this game to click so much. I really think that you could damage your hands by playing this game. At some point during my time playing the game, I started using an auto-clicker program. But what’s interesting, is that even when using auto-clicker, my hand had some phantom-limb thing going on. Like just the thought of playing this game made my hand feel uncomfortable, even though I wasn’t clicking anymore. My right forearm still feels a little hurt as I type this.

The game crashes by alt tabbing out of the game.

The game crashes by pressing the windows key.

They limit the pets that you can use to 3. So many pets aren’t good. Like the ones that feeds your pet or the fish making one, they take so long to do it that it’s really pointless to use them when you can make those with just a click.

Levels take too long and the points needed to beat a level keep getting higher and higher. Like, yes, as a game you should have that, but the devs were cruel and evil in doing what they did. Basically, for each level you have to get the required amount of points three times. So say you’d have to get 10k, then you’d have to get it 3 times. With the bosses that come in, and who can easily kill your best characters, it makes the game unforgiving. Because those expensive fish, don’t run away from the bosses. They just do their own thing and get killed. I think the devs are dumb to have made levels take so long to complete. It makes me wonder if they even played their own game. And I honestly doubt that they beat their own game. It’s so stupid.

The octopus boss sucked.

The star potion I hard to use. Even though I drop it into the tank from above, most of the time no one eats it and then it explodes on the ground. It’s just a waste of money to use, but you are forced to use it for some levels. 


Conclusion
I don’t think I have anything more to say about this game. I’m just so done with this game and I want nothing more to do with it.

What sucks, is that, the game has some really great ideas and could have been a very good game but it isn’t. It’s a hard game that is cruel and torture to play. There’s just no way that a sane person could beat this game without seriously hurting their hand by giving it carpal tunnel or using auto-click. The first couple of levels are good, but going any further than that, is just wasting your life.

Dive into Delightful Aquatic Fun - Insaniquarium Deluxe Review

Rating: ★★★★☆

Insaniquarium Deluxe, a charming and addictive aquarium management game, delivers a delightful and whimsical experience that will keep you hooked for hours. With its simple yet addictive gameplay, colorful visuals, and quirky characters, it offers a refreshing break from traditional gaming genres.

The core gameplay of Insaniquarium Deluxe revolves around nurturing and caring for your own virtual aquarium. Players start with a single tank and a few basic fish, and their objective is to feed and grow the fish while fending off various challenges, including hungry aliens and pesky predators. The mechanics are easy to grasp, allowing players of all ages to jump in and start having fun.

One of the game's strengths lies in its variety of fish species and pets. From vibrant guppies to exotic and whimsical creatures, each fish has its own unique characteristics and behaviors. As you progress, you can unlock and collect new fish, each with their own special abilities, adding an element of strategy as you strive to create a harmonious and thriving aquatic ecosystem.

Insaniquarium Deluxe's visuals are bright, colorful, and pleasing to the eye. The whimsical art style and lively animations bring the underwater world to life, creating a visually engaging experience. The game's sound effects and cheerful soundtrack complement the gameplay perfectly, adding to the overall charm and immersion.

The game's progression system provides a sense of achievement and motivation. As you accumulate wealth from feeding and breeding fish, you can purchase upgrades, additional tanks, and helpful tools to enhance your aquarium. These upgrades not only improve the aesthetics but also provide practical advantages in managing and protecting your fish from various threats.

While Insaniquarium Deluxe is a joy to play, it does have a few minor drawbacks. The game's longevity can feel somewhat limited, as the core gameplay loop can become repetitive over time. Some players may also find the difficulty curve to be slightly uneven, with certain levels or challenges posing more frustration than enjoyment.

Furthermore, the lack of additional content or updates may disappoint those seeking long-term replayability. However, considering its accessible gameplay and lighthearted nature, Insaniquarium Deluxe remains an excellent choice for casual gamers or anyone looking for a relaxing and entertaining experience.

In summary, Insaniquarium Deluxe provides a delightful and addictive aquarium management experience. Its simple yet engaging gameplay, charming visuals, and amusing characters make it a perfect choice for those seeking a light-hearted and stress-free gaming session. Dive into the colorful underwater world of Insaniquarium Deluxe and witness the joy of nurturing and protecting your aquatic friends.

134440723.review:
This review was originally posted on [url=https://www.sapphic.dog/g/steam/Insaniquarium-Deluxe]my website[/url]

[h1]Why Insaniquarium?[/h1]
Insaniquarium was my introduction to PopCap Games. I remember how I stumbled upon their games in 2005. I was in elementary school, looking for free games to play on the school computers. This was before schools started to buy invasive software to block websites and spy on students. Not only did my entire class fall in love with the game, but my teacher did as well. We would all talk about it, put up fish decorations, and write reports on the game.

[h1]The UI & Theme[/h1]
Even though this was the first PopCap game I played, it's always refreshing to see the familiar PopCap starting screen. Insaniquarium has the usual selection of adventure mode, time trial, high scores, but comes with something special. You're given a virtual tank that allows you to buy fish for a screensaver. I've tried for many years to make it work on Linux, but I can't seem to make it work consistently. I have so many fond memories of the virtual tank, and seeing how much money I could get with the screensaver up.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]
Starting the adventure mode, the game does a fantastic job introducing you to the mechanics. You start out with a single fish, and feeding it allows it to grow. As it grows, it drops shells, which act as your currency. You can use those shells to buy more fish, upgrades, and the three egg pieces you need to complete the level. The upgrades can be anything from being able to drop more food at once, upgrading the quality of the food, and increasing the damage of your ray gun. The ray gun allows you to defeat the aliens who come throughout the level to eat your fish. Shooting them in the head does double damage, and depending on where you shoot them, they move throughout the tank. Losing all your fish means you failed, and need to restart the level.

[h1]The Loop[/h1]
After you buy all three egg pieces, you're given a companion to help you in the next level. You can only have three, and eventually four, and they all do something different. My strategy was to buy the fish that give you money at the start to rush the tank-specific fish. Each tank has a special fish that gives you the bulk of your money. I felt the best way to win was to use the money making companions to get them out as fast as possible, as they gave more shells than the starter guppies. After beating each of the four tanks, you're allowed to play a bonus mini-game gives you shells for your virtual tank. Essentially, shells drop from the top of the tank, and they all have different values. Clicking the same shell up to ten times doubled the value each time.

After beating all stages, you have to beat the final boss. Instead of fending off aliens from your guppies and fish, you have to defend all the companions you've gotten throughout your playthrough. I've tried for many years to save them all, but I don't think it's possible. Either way, once you beat the game, you unlock bonus mode. Bonus mode allows you to rack up shells for your virtual tank by playing through the game again, but giving a special stage after every level.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
Insaniquarium will always have a special place in my heart. I wish we saw more of the game, but after what EA did to PopCap and Plants vs. Zombies, I'm happy for the game to remain as is. This game is easy to understand and fun to play. I'll always come back and beat this game every couple years or so, and I encourage you to do the same, at least once.

[h1]Completion Record[/h1]
Absolutely. It's short, it's sweet, and the completion goal is very obvious. Completing the game feels like what you're supposed to do. I found that beating it alone left me unsatisfied, and it has so much more to offer. Add this to your backlog, and complete it.

132289265.review:
[h1]Fish, aliens and money meet in this insane aquarium game[/h1]

[b]Insaniquarium[/b] is a virtual pets simulator video game where you buy and take care of different types of fish while trying to get enough money to go to the next level. 

This game has some different game modes, but the main one (and also the inspiration for the others) is Adventure Mode where you buy and take care of different fish throughout different levels while defending them from "Alien" fish (powerful, big evil fish that try to kill your other fish) with the goal of acquiring enough money to buy upgrades, more fish and egg pieces to then hatch at the end of a level to then get a new pet that can help you in future levels.

But what are Pets? Pets are essentially your "helpers" in this game. Each one has a special skill or utility that can help you in levels. Some of these are Stinky, a snail that can grab gold dropped by fish for you. Prego, a pregnant fish that spawns Guppies (cheapest and most basic fish you can buy and a staple of this game) constantly without requiring you to buy them. Zorf, a seahorse that shoots out level 2 food pellets for your fish whenever they are hungry (these 3 being my favorite Pets).

Throughout this game and as you advance through its "worlds" (different aquariums with different backgrounds), you'll have to play with different mechanics, such as alternate Alien fish with different abilities, mechanics that can change such as giving your fish potions to give you more valuable drops or having to feed fish Guppies or other fish to get even more valuable drops and etc. While the variety is good, it can get repetitive very quickly, even more so considering the money you need to get to go to the next level increases steadily for each level, so for later levels it can really feel like a grindfest.

Also tied to repetition, this game has a lot of clicking involved in it. You click to drop food pellets, you click to get gold, you click to buy upgrades and egg pieces, you click to shoot aliens, etc. You click a lot, a [b]LOT[/b] in this game. My hands were constantly tired of clicking on later levels, which often led me to using Pets to help on that problem. That being said, I haven't spent more than 30 minutes on a level so even though they are quite click-intensive they don't last for long, so you can take a breather between each one of them.

This game has other game modes such as Time Trial, where you try to collect as much money as you can before time runs out, Challenge mode where you deal with constantly growing inflation and more and more powerful Aliens and Virtual Tank, where you use shells, a currency that is obtained by playing to buy and take care of your fish as if they were real fish. You can also take screenshots of them and even use it as a wallpaper, which is interesting but I'll be honest. I'd rather use shells for obtaining the pricey extra pets.

Insaniquarium is a very charming charming game made by Flying Bear Entertainment and published by PopCap Games. I'll be honest, I have a soft spot for this game. I remember playing it over 10 years ago and having a lot of fun. I find it extremely charming and quite lively, even though it can be quite... "insane", and I guess that's part of the appeal, in the end. So much time has passed and it's still quite a lovely, cute game about fish and... fish aliens.

Good game!

130864113.review:
Insaniquarium! Deluxe is a story driven action packed hectic survival oriented resource management game, where you click to drop food that feeds a fish. This game then opens to another realm of complexity once the fish that you fed drops a coin that you can use to buy even more food. The game trickles these complex, thought heavy mechanics across the games long playtime, so you never feel overwhelmed over not knowing the many ways to progress. However, you will still have an incredibly hectic and difficult time as alien raids will attempt to destroy your sustained ecosystem of crazy fish. These aliens can be tackled with a ray gun, which your feeding ability gets replaced by once an enemy is detected. This ray gun can be upgraded using the game currency, coins, and for a hefty sum you could purchase the ability of auto-fire and increased damage. This game doesn't only excel at combat, but you fell under pressure even when no enemy is visible. This is because every critter and fish are ticking clocks that upon running out of time, die. The game ends if you run out of fish, as you no longer have any source of money to buy more fish. The way to keep their internal clocks from running out, killing all under your watch, is to buy food as stated before. This is not the only function of money, as you can then buy a seconds fish which increases your income greatly. But this increased production comes at a risk, the more fish you buy, the harder it is to feed them, and the more you have to urgently click their dropped coins before they disappear to try and not lose out on margins of income. Once you obtain enough money however, you can buy upgrades to your food, making them higher quality and giving the ability to spawn multiple. The way to break the cycle of feeding, fighting, and buying, is to buy all 3 egg pieces, which promptly ends the game. Only a fool would think that this is the end of the experience, as the egg hatches into a helper minion selectable before each mission. You then go on defeating more threats and micromanaging your finite resources until you obtain a 4th helper. This is when the game drops a hard choice on you. You can only take 3 per mission, which means that you will have to leave some of your agents enclosed while you do the challenge. This poses a moral challenge as you have to decide to either use new people every time so they don't left out and spice the gaming experience, or you stick to a hardened strategy and leave all the others to rot, never giving them their chance to shine but you end up getting through the levels faster and succeeding easier. Moral challenges like this are littered throughout the entire game, causing you to reflect on how you treat people in the real world and vice-versa. This can draw an insightful lesson of being friends with people, not because they are helpful or that you can exploit them, but hang around with people that genuinely need it. The game then switches over to a more complex feeding system, as they introduce carnivores that drop diamonds instead of coins, and this extra financial boost is required to obtain the ever increasing price of the egg pieces. During this time, even more absurd and complex enemies spawn, such as enemies that you kill by inflating with your fish food, enemies that go into states of regaining health on shot instead of decreasing, and even enemies that fire homing rockets towards your fish that need to be deflected with advanced aerial defense mechanisms, or with your laser. The feeding and collected mechanic gets even more complex as it introduces hierarchies of fish that give birth to other fish that get eaten to feed other fish that get eaten to feed other fish that produce treasure chests. The concept of expensive fish that produce a lot provides another hard choice, to either buy it the second you have the money for faster times, or wait until you can buy it and have some money left over. The problem with the former is that if you make an investment in your high quality ultravores and an alien raid arrives, killing your beloved fish, then you will have to repeat the slow earning process, or even need to restart if it causes a game over. But if you do the latter, you might end up spending a long time just waiting until you have enough money, just thinking about how much money you could get with the ultravore if you were to buy him. All of these complex mechanics and more are wrapped up in the incredible ending, where you defeat the mastermind alien behind all of the crazy attacks. The battle takes place with all of the special units collect among the levels, and you have to protect them as he slowly eats all of your favorite characters as they wait defenseless, waiting for you to step in as a mist of blood replaces where they once lived, where they once laughed, where they once loved. Upon defeating this evil guy you are greeted with a tear-jerking credits screen including some of your favorite characters, such as: Green fish. Red fish. Blue fish. Yellow fish. Purple fish. Crab. Orange fish.
To sum it up, Insaniquarium! Deluxe is a masterpiece of an experience, a true concept that was way ahead of its time. This game does what most games can't and makes you question the hypothetical world around you.
Overall, 11/10

125255467.review:
I have to admit that I first played this game in something that gave me a limited number of sessions for free. It took me years later to buy this game on Steam.

PROS:
Is better than the Flash version, but that's to be expected as this is that turned into a full game
You can amuse yourself by thinking that the way fish drop money is by pooping them (no official explanation is given)
You don't have to worry about several real-world aspects of keeping fish, like filters, though aliens invade your tank with the goal of eating all your fish
There are fish that change colors and cycle through the rainbow in the Virtual Tank (they sometimes replace the colored guppies and carnivores usually available with changing colors each day, and the color changing ones cost five times as much as ones that have a static palette)
Fish in the Virtual Tank that eat other fish won't eat store-bought fish, so you feed them with a button that lets you feed anything that doesn't eat the standard fish food.
This is where Stinky the Snail, who later appeared in the Zen Garden in Plants Vs. Zombies, debuted

CONS:
Virtual Tank is more long-term than you'd expect due to restocking at midnight and how the store slot for fish with special attributes is on a twenty-day cycle
Could damage your mouse due to all the clicking you have to do (unless you get an auto-clicker, but even then, aliens have invincibility frames each time you hit them).

If you want to revisit your childhood (or play this game for the first time), go for it.

This went from a fun game I remember playing as a kid, to a striking criticism about capitalism
You go from protecting the fish because you like them, to seeing them as money makers for the ever going economy that is your fish tank.
Food turns from a commodity to a luxury as there's never enough to go around
Dozens succumb to starvation, and hundreds to the predators you willingly put in your tank because it makes you more money.
From weeping over a single fish dying to an alien, to complete indifference to hundreds dying every level.
But the fish tank must grow.
The greed must be sated.
It can never end.
10/10

So much nostalgia! Insaniquarium is a game I used to play endlessly, ages ago, I think as a browser game on Yahoo. I was thrilled to see it on steam, and nabbed it on sale. 
It's tons of fun to revisit, and even if you're not already familiar, it's a fun aquarium management game to get you furiously clicking away.

You start off with a fish tank, and a fish, and the ability to click to give that fish some food. The fish will grow up, give you a little money every so often, and from there you unlock new abilities, new fish, and make a whole different strategy.

It's a lot of fun to try out different strategies and figure out how to survive the perils of fish ownership. 

I got way further than I ever used to as a kid, further than I ever thought there was! 10/10, well worth the experience.

117834213.review:
This game is truly a testament to what it was like growing up in the early 2000s with nothing more than a family computer.

100 HOUR EDIT: The plot really starts picking up around this time. While I still have yet to feel that I've reached the story's climax, I do think that good things are in store. Most definitely never reached this point as a child. Will update as things get better.

250 HOUR EDIT: I can NOT believe that the aliens did that!!!! You absolutely HAVE to play this game until this point. It's a bit slow to get to the 100 hour point, but things most definitely pick up after that, and the following 150 hours are utterly irreplaceable. Truly a perfect game. I will never regret my time spent on this so far.

500 HOUR EDIT: I recently noticed that my performance in game was slowly degrading. Hopefully the RTX 3080 I bought for this game will make it run at a buttery smooth 60 frames again. The plot has picked up tremendously, but I can most definitely tell that it has more in store if I just keep at it. No spoilers, but I absolutely did NOT think that the mermaid would do THAT. Definitely earns the certified M rating from me.

1000 HOUR EDIT: My girlfriend has left me and I have been fired from my job. This game has utterly taken over my life and I cannot stop playing it. The fish VS alien race war is well underway and there is no current clear winner. Both sides are taking extreme losses. I am stuck in the middle of this conflict. If I do not play the game, the fish will lose, but if I keep playing this game my entire life will be forfeit to the mermaid. SHE IS A LIE. I will keep you updated. This game is better than any other I have ever played and is entirely worth my life falling apart.

1800 HOUR EDIT: This game is an addiction. For nearly a year, I was able to put it away and not think about the world of my aquarium. In a single moment of weakness, I noticed that the screensaver to my epic gamer PC was my aquarium of which I poured over 1000 hours into... and I broke. For days now, I have done nothing but play this game. I've been fired from my job and my boyfriend has left me. In a single moment, this life I had built up has been completely ruined. This 2001 game of the year continues to light up my life and be the only reason that I continue to wake up each morning. I've finally gotten to the end of the Guppy story ark. I shudder thinking of what is to come.

This is an extremely old game I grew up playing.
There's not much to it:
You buy fish (guppies, carnivores, ultravores, etc.). You have to feed them, collecting the money they drop (poop?) to buy eggshell pieces. As you're doing this, an alien will teleport into your tank and try to eat all the fish; you get equipped a laser to zap it to smithereens.

After every egg is completed, you unlock a brand new pet that'll help you in your adventure.

Yeah, the game sounds weird, but give it a try; it's fast, entertaining, enjoyable. This is a fun arcade game to play to pass the time.

116011377.review:
Insaniquarium Deluxe is, perhaps, the greatest game ever created by man. If there's one work of art you could showcase as definitive proof that not only a higher power exists, but that they were benevolent enough to give us the insight and ability to create that they may have, none would be more fitting than this game- nay, this [i]experience[/i]. 
The time I've spent in this game may be brief, but it has given me the experience of thousands of lifetimes. All the carpal tunnel, the RSI, the self-improvement I've put off, is all worth it for Insaniquarium. The wonderfulness of relationships or of watching your children grow and develop or whatever other societal goals may be seen as most fulfilling all pale in comparison to the joy of purchasing 1/3 of the egg. Every piece, every third, is a step towards a greater conclusion, and the experience of getting that final piece and completing the level- pure [i]bliss[/i]. All to start anew, going through the motions again, just like the rest of life. 
Insaniquarium is a reminder that, despite the difficulties, the stress, the monotony, and the aliens of our everyday existence, there will always be a light at the end of the tunnel. Every fish I feed, every level I complete, every enemy I fend off, all contributes to my growth towards eternal enlightenment. This game is mankind's greatest achievement, and the pinnacle of human expression through art.

114918359.review:
Do you remember that time when you used to sit at the playground swing as the evening afternoon slowly came to an end? Maybe you were in middle school, high school, some small child who stared blankly outwards towards a world you didn't even know you were so blatantly ignorant to. All you knew then was that you wanted to swing on that swing for hours and hours and never go home. 

A chill might have crept up your back then, as a soft wind beckoned the oncoming of nighttime, and you knew in your heart that you needed to go back home, back to your parents and your siblings and your family pet and all the small things you kept in the little corner you called your world. You might've wanted to sit on that swing for hours and hours, or swing on that monkey bar until your arms fell off. You wanted to run in that park field until you collapsed from laughter and exhaustion, or ran through those thickets and wooded areas your parents told you not to go into. You might've wanted to chase your friends around in a never-ending game of chase, or hide forever in that one little spot you knew by heart. 

But as you grew up, you found yourself attracted by the myriad vagaries of life. You might've gone on that first date, or gone far away from home for some nebulous reason you don't know. Maybe you decided you hated what things had become, or who you were becoming, or blamed life for misery, for suffering, for the conditions intrinsic to human existence itself. Maybe you sat by yourself at times, wondering who you were, where you were going, why things were the way they were. Always looking for answers in the wrong places, always searching for the next high, the next fad that'd distract you from the emptiness gnawing within you. 

And when you became an adult, you found yourself again looking blankly, but backwards this time. Wondering where had all that time gone, why hadn't things turned out the way you wanted? Who was I still, and what was important to me? Questions of philosophy and human intricacies might've ran rampant within you, struggling with your body and spirit as you split yourself into a veritable crowd of personalities, all fighting bitterly for conquest and dominion over your eternal soul. 

But when I sat for a few minutes and played Insaniquarium, I felt all at once an uneasy peace come over me. 

For my restless soul that bound itself to conflict and purposeful self-inflicted pain, who knew all at once what was right and wrong and yet chose wrong and rejected right. 

As I dropped these fish pellets I floated in my own fish tank, empty and blank, seeing nothing but a horizon of the rising sun, the distant sky tinged in a pallet of orange and green. 

And as the sweet, soft music played I felt a hot streak come down my cheek, and was overcome with shame at what I was and was not. 

And when my fish died, I died with them. 

And when they grew up happily and in contentedness, I grew with them in equal measure. 

I fought the demons and the aliens, and struggled for lives that were not my own. 

And when it ended, and I beheld all those creatures and companions I had acquired and protected over those many levels, who could say that it had been merely a video game? 

Beyond the veil of childish design and simplicity I looked upon an ageless beauty, feeling redemption undeserved for a tired and weary soul. Comfort and joyous light brushed my cheeks, and all at once my ego was shattered into a thousand pieces. 

Like a Rosetta stone of love, this game will forever be ingrained into the crevices of my heart, for all my days.

113054737.review: This is a wonderfully quirky take on a fish tank simulator that combines the fairly routine act of feeding your fish and collecting the coins that inexplicably fall out of them with occasional alien attacks. Each level has the goal of purchasing three egg pieces from the HUD's shop. Each fish drops a different type of currency based on its maturity or type, and the more valuable the fish's drops are, the more expensive the fish itself is. This means every fish is a risk, because if you drop a large sum of money to buy a fish and it dies before you get back what it cost, you are now that much farther from reaching your goal of collecting all three egg pieces. And each time you do reach the end of a level, you gain a new pet that will assist you. You can have three pets of your choice for any given level, and the ones you choose can drastically change the way you approach a level, as does the combination of pets you choose. The alien attacks can be genuinely heart-pounding due to their deadly efficiency at taking down fish. Some pets can mitigate the aliens' destructive force by either attacking the aliens themselves, or luring your fish to a safe spot in the tank, but that takes up a spot that could be used for collecting more money, and getting you closer to clearing the stage. The levels are split up in different worlds, referred to as tanks. Each tank has its own fish to keep healthy, and aliens to fend off, which keeps the gameplay from feeling stale. I can't deny I'm very biased, as I've been playing it longer than I can remember, but it's a truly fun experience that I can't recommend enough if you're into resource management.

111714170.review:
Insaniquarium is a casual, short, Tycoon-like game that asks the player to maintain an aquarium in order to gain coins, gems, and other various forms of currency. This currency is used to buy food, upgrade the quality or quantity of food, buy more fish, and a few other options available depending on the world.
The player is also asked to protect their fish from the dastardly, murderous intervention of various aliens, all with their own obstructive patterns.

There is an additional gameplay mode, which allows you to curate and maintain an aquarium of your own, with additional skins for the fish you encounter in game. You purchase these fish using a currency earned by completing sections of the game, called shells. This mechanic features a minigame where you click on various forms of the shell currency to collect it. If you click on the same type of shell, it accrues value until you click on another type of shell, or until you finish the combo. 

There is a semblance of a story, mostly filled in by the player's imagination, and by the credit sequence. 

While this game likely does not match the standards of many current gamers, this game still carries fond memories of many people who were simply looking for a game that felt like it was alive. If you recall spending days at a time pouring your attention into this game, you may find it refreshing to turn off the outside world and re-explore a tank of your own.

106765265.review:
This game gets a C for gmaeplay, but an A+ for originality. 

Seriously, if this gameplay was anything other than "click wildly 100% of the time until you can't feel your fingers anymore", this would be a masterpiece.  But that's what you get here -- a game that is so much about clicking that I can barely play it for more than 20 minutes at a time.  That's not an exaggeration, it's about 20 minutes until my fingers go numb from clicking as wildly as I can, and I have to take a little break before I jump back in.

You can probably play this game more casually than I do, but not by much... and if you're like me and you wanna get through every level as quickly as possible, you're never going to stop clicking once it gets going.  It's a real problem for long-term play, unlike any other game I've played to be honest.  I've never had to bail from a game for finger fatigue almost at all before, never mind consistently.

However, this massive downside aside, this game is still really neat.  It's a FISHTANK with a STORY MODE.  So, despite any gameplay flaws, it's the best FISHTANK with a STORY MODE game that's ever been on the market.  Anything bad about this game can't knock it off the #1 spot of FISHTANK with a STORY MODE games.

And for that reason alone, I really love it.  It's very unique, and it's from that fun age of gaming I love to revisit.  I bet most people come back to this because they remember it fondly, but I only came back because a coworker remembered it fondly and made me want to buy it.  I think it's important to mention that, even without any nostalgia attached to this game, I found it really enjoyable to play through.

MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD:  The main gameplay loop is to earn enough money with your fishtank to buy an egg that will unlock a new special creature to help you in future tanks.  You can take three with you, and they do a bunch of different stuff which helps you try and go for certain 'fishtank builds' if you will.  Beyond that, each fishtank has a different money requirement, and each set of five fishtanks has a different set of fish you can put in it.  You might have to max out guppies in the early levels for coins, but later levels will have you upgrading those guppies to star guppies by feeding them a potion only when big.  You'll soon notice the star doesn't even give as much as the guppy gold coin before and feel ripped off, until you notice Starcatchers can turn those stars into diamonds worth 5x as much.  So now you have guppies growing up, converted into star guppies, dropping stars you can't touch until they convert to diamonds for max profit.  There's a bunch more like that I won't go into detail about, but my main point is that it's not just a "put fish, feed fish, get money" game, there's little themes and puzzles to figure out along the way.  The speedrun for this game must be crazy, can't wait to check it out after I've played through everything.

The maim story goes by pretty fast, but there's some extra modes and some grindy unlockables for people that don't want to be done with the game that soon.  I haven't tried them all, but there seems to be some time trials and an open fishtank casual mode, which could be neat.  I wouldn't expect hundreds of hours out of this game, but if it had hundreds of hours of gameplay I don't think I'd want to play it all anyways, so it feels right.  It's got more than enough fun for it's price, if you can look past some really outdated gameplay (why can't I click and drag to collect coins?? so close...) it's definitely worth killing a few afternoons on.

106641717.review:
I am 48.

My ex-wife and I have adopted both a son and daughter together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some drywall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest gamer with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the parent I needed to be in that moment, not the weak drywall-puncher I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

 ultimately one day at best buy, i was probably age 8, i saw the game once more, i begged my mom and step dad to buy it, and let me tell you no excitement will ever amount to that second when i convinced them to let me get it. i went home later that night and installed it on our family computer, and showed all of my siblings the magnificence of this piece of art. 
 during my time of playing it i had almost beat the whole game, until my little brother maliciously decided he would delete all of our accounts, i was distraught, i haven’t experienced pain worse then at that time, or so i thought, i almost beat the game yet again, until my parents decided to throw away our computer. alas, my insane aquarium cd was still in the disc drive! in that minute i didn’t even know how to cope with it, this loss was one i will never forget.
 in early 2020 when looking for games i would wanna buy and play on steam, i immediately thought about this game and my love for it, so i immediately looked for it, i was ecstatic when i found out i could get it on here, all i needed was to buy it for a small price of $4.99. i planned on purchasing it when i had the funds, but my boyfriend at the time surprised me and bought it for me instead, i don’t even know if they knew how much that meant to me, i cried because of how euphoric that time was for me, (and when i said no excitement will ever amount to what i felt when i got it when i was 8 i lied, because in that moment exceeded that feeling by far.)
i ended up finishing the game and enjoyed every second i spent playing it.

anyways to finish my dramatic review about my love for this game, i will explain what the objective of this game is.
basically it’s a clicker game that has you start with little guppies, and you want to feed them so they get bigger, the bigger they are the more money they give you, (guppies don’t give you money though) eventually you will get different types of “fish” that give you money, and when getting that money you are trying to upgrade the food you feed them, the gun you use (more on that later), and other things like more fish or “fish”. in the midst of the game you will have random aliens fight and try to eat you fishys, your job is to protect them, kill the aliens, and keep your fish alive as long as possible. what is the main reason for earning and collecting money you ask? well the goal is to save up enough money to buy a special egg slowly, you buy it in parts, and the more rare the egg is the more expensive it will be. these special eggs will turn into special little helper pets that will do different tasks to assist you in keeping your fish alive, or get you to your end goal of collecting the special eggs.
one of my personal favorite parts is the personal aquarium you get to have, you get to buy, name, and keep fish that will never die in your personal tank, they too will give you money, the money is worth a lot less, and not even close to as much as you would get if you were to be playing the, for a lack of a better word “campaign”.
 i don’t want to go too much into detail, because i genuinely recommend giving it a try, it is honestly an amazing game to turn your brain off and just play, .•˚✧₊⁎*~to a point~*⁎⁺˳✧༚•., it’s just the right amount of challenging and fun. so overall 1,000,000/10 would replay again, and again, and again, and again, infact if i had my laptop on me right now i would be playing it right now! (ृ ´͈ ᵕ `͈ ृ )ु

93388403.review:
Incredible nostalgia, very fun concept with great replay-ability, made by the same man who made the original Plants Vs. Zombies, this game holds the same charm and same incredible gameplay, you go through several different "tanks"(worlds) in the main story, the first being completely basic and mostly a tutorial, but all the others having unique enemies, ecosystems, fish, pets(specialty creatures you can bring into a level with you with special abilities), and things to unlock for your next playthroughs etc. even after clearing the entire "story" for the first time there's still an INCREDIBLE amount of stuff left to do. You can try to get the high score on time trials for easy money for your shop, or do an INCREDIBLY challenging "challenge" mode where enemies become literally EXPONENTIALLY more difficult with time, and every item's price increases overtime, if you're able to complete a challenge you get a piece of backstory from the game, making it so you can play each challenge mode again and again! You have a personal fish tank where you can get many odd fish, from being able to get singing volley balls to being able to raise the enemies themselves(friendly ones of course). The game also has a KILLER soundtrack and some pretty fine art design, along with the MANY Easter Eggs of this game, this game just has it all.
The game will always hold a special place in my heart, and it may just be childhood bias, but this is one of my more favored games that I've played over these many years, and I recommend buying it 100%!

88322875.review:
I remember being a part of the Fish Vs. Alien Wars from the mid-2000's. I remember the lives I've failed to save all those years ago...the battles I've won, the ones I've lost, the feeling of my index finger clicking away at those aliens that I have never forgotten about from over a decade ago.

And now they've returned.

Our weapons have changed since then, our clicks per minute, our FPS, everything has improved since then, but the enemy remains just as vigilant as they were the first time they entered our world. I grabbed my mouse, and began clicking once more. The sensations never faded away, I remembered everything from the smiles on my fish as I fed them to the looks of the aliens terrified faces as I blast them to smithereens.

Once again I join the watery battlefield, taking care of the ones that are so helpless that all they can do is swim away from the aliens, but alas, their tiny minds make them oblivious to all the danger. Is it a gift to not know you are swimming directly towards the one who will eat you whole in a single bite? To be so blind to the threat in front of you? I do not know, but I do know it pains me every time that one of my fish swims towards their watery grave which is inside an alien's stomach.

They give me so little, but I treasure each and every coin I can manage to click on. They give me so much, yet I can only click so fast. My index finger grows stronger by the day, with the ability to carry all the groceries in on a single finger, the ability to lift a 5-pound weight on a single finger all while maintaining a tender grace on my weapon, clicking away at the alien threat until all my fish are safe.

Some of the fish join my cause, offering to collect the gifts the fish give me along with offering protection. My strongest ones can barely hold themselves together anymore, often eating or killing my fish to maintain their sanity and fight for our cause. The aliens have done more than killing us, they changed us, drove us mad as we worry for every life under our watch, yet the goal of keeping every fish safe is impossible as they mindlessly swim in any direction they wish, oblivious to the war around us that carries on every day.

A gift, or a curse? We may never know...

This is the war that takes place under the sea, this is the place that so few come out unscathed, your index finger will break, you will break, your mind may snap, you may wish that it would just end, that the war will finally be over, we pray every day for that, that someday we may finally let out a sigh of relief as the aliens finally call forth a full-retreat and fall back to their home world.

A foolish wish it is, yet it gives us hope, and it keeps us clicking away...

This is Insaniquarium.

86737424.review:
One of my favourite games when I was younger. I'm so happy I got to play this again.

This game is lots of fun and has a very friendly vibe so it can appeal to most audiences. In terms of gameplay, your job is to feed the fish and defend them from threats until you can earn enough money to complete the level. As you progress through the game, keeping certain fish alive becomes more complicated and defending against threats can become more difficult too. As you continue, you'll also unlock new pets that you can keep around to help you complete levels or just to make the tank more interesting.

When you're tired of the main game, there's a Virtual Tank where you can relax and appreciate your own personal fish tank with permanent fish that you can feed and observe.

It's just as fun and frantic as I remember and I can't wait to finish it again. I believe a slightly updated version or remaster of this game would work very well. Add more game content, Steam achievements, make it work better with wider aspect ratios and add other modern features like visiting other players' Virtual Tanks. I'd be happy to buy it again for that.

-----

For those who don't know it, this game was PopCap's best game (in my opinion) before [i]Plants vs Zombies[/i]. For the 3 people in the world who haven't played [i]Plants vs Zombies[/i] yet, if you enjoyed [i]Insaniquarium[/i], PvZ is your next stop!

Disclaimer: I haven't beaten this game.
Story: What story? There's aliens and they want to eat your coin producing fish. Story won't be factored.
Gameplay 5/10: You can choose from a variety of pets to have that can do anything from make fish to killing aliens. You then start with some fish, and can buy more. You have to feed your fish so they produce money for you. Your goal is to buy all 3 pieces of the egg to finish the level and get a new pet. But sometimes aliens invade. They want to kill your fish, so kill them with your laser gun. Very simple, and can drag on after a while. Your index finger is also destined to get cramped for a while.
Looks 3/5: This game screams 2000's PopCap, and it's pretty nice. No where as good looking as, say, Plants VS. Zombies, but still looks solid.
Music 4/5: The tunes are very simple, but very catchy. 
Accessibility 0/5: This was back in 2006, when there wasn't much talk about accessibility, but it doesn't excuse a complete lack of accessibility options. Just music options! That's it! There's literally nothing.
Overall Score: 12/25, or 48/100
Enjoyment Score: 7/10
When would I recommend? Sale
This is only a thumbs down because it's below the halfway point. I'd say it's an interesting cornerstone in PopCap's history, but otherwise, it's just... fine.
